bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 24, 1940

div1.p: Andrus sends Truby his chapter entitled "I Become a Guinea Pig," but states that he doesn't want to claim undue credit for his role.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 24, 1940
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
10-24-40
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
I am enclosing the chapter, “I Become a Guinea Pig”, referred
to in my letter of the twentieth. As turn about is said
to be fair play, I hope you will let me have your frank crit-
icism. I have endeavored to check everything but, as you
have found, there are many things not covered in the printed
reports.

The roll of honor, which appears on the last page, is some-
thing of an appendage. I could not find any place in the
body of the narrative where it fit in and I did not want any-
one who reads it to get the impression that the experiments
were conducted by “me and Major Reed”. There has been a
distinct “me and Major Reed” flavor to some matter I have
read which was based on interviews with volunteers.

Lambert has not yet advised me whether he wants your manu-
script sent him. It has occured to me that, in the mean-
time, you may wish to proceed with your revision. With
that in mind, I am enclosing a copy of the comments I have
attached to the manuscript.

Lambert made some additions to the diagram of the post hos-
pital at Columbia Barracks which were not understandable and
had to be returned to him.
